image.altText: Mitch Marsh and Pat Cummins complete a high five in celebration of a wicket

items.synopsis: Australia takes three wickets late on day one at Headingley after Mitch Marsh's blistering 118 carries the side from the brink of disaster to respectability in the third Test.

title.children: Late wickets and Mitch Marsh's brilliance rescue Australia from disastrous day one at Headingley

image.altText: Ross Fox wearing a dark business suit, sitting at a small with four energetic school students writing in their notepads.

items.synopsis: Universities will be given two years to overhaul their education degrees or risk losing their accreditation as part of a national bid to fix Australia's teacher shortage.

title.children: Dissatisfied with university teaching degrees, Ross retrained more than 1,000 teachers. The results were huge

image.altText: Plants in a cylinder-like chamber.

items.synopsis: The scientists behind the project are aiming to grow plants on the lunar surface within four years, something they hope will in turn allow for the development of food, medicine and oxygen in the hostile environment.

title.children: Australian start-up aiming to grow plants on the Moon receives $3.6m in government funding

image.altText: Mitch Marsh closes his eyes as he holds his bat and helmet up

items.synopsis: It came out of nowhere and ended just as abruptly, but Mitch Marsh's incredible century proved critical on a day that England found new Ashes life in some Mark Wood thunderbolts.

title.children: Mitch Marsh's magnificent fever dream keeps Australia alive on rollicking day one at Headingley

image.altText: A close up of a man leaning against a helicipter while wearing fatigues and protective equipment

items.synopsis: Baruch's only son was suddenly killed in military action. Now he's fighting for permission to use his son's sperm to create a grandchild.

title.children: How much power should a parent have? Amit is dead but his father saved his sperm

image.altText: Torn pieces of paper forming the head shoulders and obscured faces of a doctor with a face mask and stethoscope

items.synopsis: Almost 730 registered health professionals were accused of inappropriate behaviour or sexual misconduct by patients in the last financial year, new figures reveal.

title.children: Doctors, nurses investigated amid 'distressing' surge in sexual misconduct against patients

image.altText: A middle-aged Indigenous woman with long dark hair stands behind a lectern filled with microphones.

items.synopsis: Earlier, the government was putting much faith in "the vibe" to carry the Voice – a general appeal to righting the wrongs of the past and giving Indigenous people the opportunity to be heard. Now the government is desperate to arrest the slide, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: The new 'prime target' in government's battle to stop the slide in Yes vote

image.altText: Liam Broady puts his hands to his ears on Centre Court at Wimbledon

items.synopsis: Stan Wawrinka set up what looms as a potentially epic showdown with Novak Djokovic and Australia's men recorded a trifecta of victories but the day belonged to the most unlikely of local British heroes as Centre Court erupted for a massive upset.

title.children: Murray mound? Make it Broady's boulder. Wimbledon erupts as local hope records huge upset on Centre Court

image.altText: England captain Ben Stokes puts his arm around an angry Joe Root in the field during an Ashes Test.

items.synopsis: Joe Root and Jonny Bairstow dropped crucial chances for England as Mitch Marsh capitalised and Mark Wood hit top speed on his return. Here are the five things you missed overnight on day one of the third Ashes Test at Headingley.

title.children: Five quick hits — Sloppy fielding costs England dear as two players make triumphant Test returns

image.altText: A set of shelves with papers and a collection of wigs laid out on them.

items.synopsis: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, who last month brokered a deal to end an armed mutiny in Russia, says Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin is no longer in Belarus.

title.children: Prigozhin is not in Belarus, Lukashenko says, as Moscow shows off wigs, guns and fake ID from Wagner boss's home

image.altText: A young Indigenous man looks away from the camera smiling.

items.synopsis: Skydiving isn't always how Marley imagined he'd get his kicks, but ever since he was a kid, he's been chasing the thrill.

title.children: Marley's search for excitement almost put him behind bars. Then he found a way to harness the high

image.altText: Two Year 12 students use laptops at John Paul College.

items.synopsis: Mobile phones and smart watches will be banned from all state schools, in a move to bring Queensland's policy in line with the rest of the country.

title.children: Mobile phones and smart watches to be banned in all Queensland state schools, government confirms

image.altText: A photo of a white submersible under water.

items.synopsis: OceanGate, the US based company that managed the imploded Titanic submersible, suspends all exploration and commercial operations.

title.children: Titanic sub operator suspends expeditions after deadly implosion

image.altText: Ice in the ocean

items.synopsis: Over the past few weeks, climate records have shattered across the globe. So what's going on with the climate, and why are we seeing all these records tumbling at once? asks Kimberley Reid.

title.children: Why are so many climate records breaking all at once?

image.altText: A snow covered ski resort with people walking around in padded clothes

items.synopsis: Light snow started falling on Thursday afternoon and should continue through Friday, before increasing at the weekend when a powerful cold front crosses south-east Australia.

title.children: Half-metre dump predicted for Australia's snow resorts — but skiing conditions might not be ideal

image.altText: Alyce Tippett explains what she loves about motorsport

items.synopsis: What will it take to pave the way for female V8 supercar drivers to compete in Australia's biggest motorsport events?

title.children: Alyce dreams of competing with the best in her field. She hopes being a woman won't stop her

image.altText: Mischa Perz stands wearing a black top and pinke beanie, in the boxing ring

items.synopsis: Two construction workers on a major Victorian government project are filmed yelling at a small business owner over a parking dispute she says could cost her her business.

title.children: How a long-running parking spat is threatening to destroy Mischa's business

image.altText: A hand is shown parting venetian blinds to enable a person to look out a window.

items.synopsis: The program funds community housing providers in Darwin and Alice Springs to sub-lease properties to people escaping domestic violence and at risk of homelessness.

title.children: DV is the leading cause of homelessness in the NT. This program aims to change that

image.altText: A kangaroo hops through the inside of a country style pub

items.synopsis: Farmers in NSW's west say they haven't seen numbers like these since the early years of the last drought, but long-term data tells the population has halved over 20 years.

title.children: Boom in kangaroo numbers worries farmers, as activists say population is in decline

image.altText: A woman stands in a white dress in the rain.

items.synopsis: Former Canberra political staffer Brittany Higgins says she has received a "concerns notice" from WA senator Linda Reynolds threatening legal action, with the senator declaring she "will not tolerate being defamed".

title.children: Brittany Higgins says WA senator Linda Reynolds has threatened to sue her over Instagram post

image.altText: Graphic showing AFL stadium at Mac Point superimposed over historic goods shed which is in the same spot

items.synopsis: A historic goods shed in Hobart that's in the exact spot of a proposed AFL stadium could soon be given heritage protection — and that could be a problem for the project.

title.children: Hobart is getting a new stadium — but a unique piece of Australian rail history is in the way

image.altText: Elderly woman turns her eyes to the side to look at camera with bandana on head

items.synopsis: A trauma resource kit has been entirely developed by a group of senior Warlpiri women to help their community take the first steps towards healing.

title.children: Childhood trauma has a grip in remote Yuendumu. But these women are working to bring healing

image.altText: A group of New Zealand Maori men, dressed in soccer uniforms, perform the haka

items.synopsis: First Nations footballers from the neighbouring countries have been competing in a series of games ahead of the FIFA World Cup. They hope it'll lead to an Indigenous competition on the global stage.

title.children: Australia and New Zealand First Nations footballers hope historic series will lead to Indigenous World Cup

image.altText: Young women hold hands in support.

items.synopsis: When Colony 47 first opened its doors, not everyone was pleased about who they were welcoming in. Fifty years on, the Tasmanian organisation remains committed to being a welcoming space for all.

title.children: 'I was attacked from every direction': Colony 47 founder on 50 year fight to help young Tasmanians

image.altText: Tony Abbott sits in a chair with his hands in his lap.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Tony Abbott says a constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament is "wrong in principle" and will reinforce "separatism" in Australia.

title.children: Voice to Parliament 'damaging in the long term', former PM Tony Abbott says

image.altText: Hemsworth and Threads composite

items.synopsis: More than 30 million users sign up to Meta's Twitter rival in 18 hours according to Mark Zuckerberg, with Australian celebrities and political leaders amongst the first users.

title.children: Thirty million users rush to join Threads in platform's first day as Twitter continues 'toppling itself'

image.altText: serbia vucic

items.synopsis: Serbia's president Aleksandar Vucic accuses Kosovo of carrying out "silent ethnic cleansing" of Serbs and says his country will seek a meeting with NATO's chief and an urgent session of United Nations Security Council to demand their protection.

title.children: Serbia's president accuses Kosovo of carrying out 'silent ethnic cleansing'

image.altText: A composite image showing a middle-aged man with an odd expression and a middle-aged woman.

items.synopsis: The younger Trump, who had been booked on a three-day tour that was scheduled to begin in Sydney on Sunday, cancelled the trip on Wednesday, with organisers suggesting the reason was visa issues. Ms O'Neil says that wasn't the case.

title.children: Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil calls Donald Trump Jr a 'big baby' over cancelled Australian speaking tour

image.altText: Jai Hindley looks down

items.synopsis: Jai Hindley cracks on the Col du Tourmalet to surrender the Tour de France yellow jersey as Tadej Pogačar wins stage six ahead of Jonas Vingegaard.

title.children: Jai Hindley explodes on the Tourmalet to surrender yellow jersey

image.altText: A group of women with microphones dancing on stage

items.synopsis: The organiser of a Blackpink concert in Hanoi apologises after its website featured a map showing China's territorial claims in the South China Sea, as Vietnam authorities launch an inspection into the incident.

title.children: Blackpink embroiled in latest South China Sea controversy
